S.ex: she's a cut above the rest.
S.cprop: noun, often an agent or person.
S.com: same as "better than"; close enough to others sharing the type.

entry.S: • preposition (of a dish) cooked or prepared in a specified way: fish cooked à la meunière.Backdrop1(1)Cookeryà laDish1 2a 3b*a proper name; a culinary termname of a prepared dish; adj or participle denoting food preparation(core)

ms.ex: afternoon talk shows à la Oprah.

S.cprop: a proper name
S.aprop: concrete or abstract noun; verb or participle denoting creation or execution
S.srel: 3: generalizing extension to cover items other than food

entry.S: • preposition nearer the stern than; behind.Spatial1(1)NauticalabaftShipPart1 2a 3a*behindpart of a shipverbs of location; nouns denoting ship partscore: locationNautical use only; otherwise =1(1) of "behind."

I climbed aboard the yacht.Spatial1(1)aboardaboardConveyance1 2a 3a9.15-16in, on, ontoa conveyance, usu prec by determiner or possessiveverbs of motion, mounting, embarking.core: conveyanceSame as on 16(7b)

eg.ex: with Richard Migliore aboard, he won the cup at a gallop.

ms.df: so as to affect:
ms.ex: there's nothing we can do about it.

S.fepreps: about; for; of; in; to; at; on; over; among; into; onto; with; towards; upon; against; as;
S.cprop: any NP; sth affected by the POA
S.srel: 2: specific to cases where the subject of consideration is affected
S.com: In the most general way, easily subsumed by the core sense.

Am choice for this is nearly always "around"

ms.df: around

S.frfes: Body_movement:Goal; Cause_motion:Goal; Cause_to_move_in_place:Fixed_location; Dispersal:Goal_area; Hair_configuration:Location; Manipulation:Locus; Mass_motion:Area; Perception_active:Ground; Placing:Goal; Self_motion:Path
S.fepreps: against; to; out; over; into; on; behind; beneath; in; about; above; across; along; around; beside; at; before; by; up; onto; upon; towards; away; under; inside; outside; between; back; directly; down; firmly; closer; underneath; within; below; close; all; amongst; among; deeper; through; from; off; beyond; with; anywhere; deep; somewhere; the; aro; alongside; a; centrally; near; either; next; right; just; capacious; after; toward; past; for; due; forwards; further; straight; stinking; via; even; less; though;

S.aprop: verbs of motion and perception; other activities

entry.S: 3. chiefly Brit. used to express location in a particular place: rugs were strewn about the hall | he produced a knife from somewhere about his person.Spatial4(3)aboutPlace2a 3a9.22Scrutiny:Groundaround, in, throughoutfor; of; on; from; in; into; within; back; beneath; between; beyond; about; among; around; through; under; at; over; up; a space, literal or abstractverbs of location; objects that can be located in space2: specific to location without the idea of movementODE: chiefly Brit. Am choice for this is nearly always "around"

ms.df: used to describe a quality apparent in a person:
ms.ex: there was a look about her that said everything.

S.fepreps: about; of; over; by; on; in; to; against; upon; with; as;
S.cprop: a person; a thing with attributes
S.srel: 1: attribute as a metaphor of location
S.com: Could easily be a core sense, and closer in meaning to sense 1 than here. ODE falsely limits the comp to persons; I've expanded it, to include both "there was a look about her that said everything" and "there is something absurd about that marriage."

entry.S: • preposition

1. in extended space over and not touching: a display of fireworks above the town | a cable runs above the duct.Spatial1(1)aboveThingSurmounted1 2a 3b9.19Fluidic_motion:Area; Motion_directional:Areaover, on top ofabove; around; in; inside; beside; on; behind; at; over; a physical entity that can have sth above itwide range of POSs. No patterncore: upwards frommore or less identical to over 1(1)

ms.df: extending upwards over:
ms.ex: she held her arms above her head.

S.fepreps: onto; in; into; on; for; round; over; around; above; across; directly; through; under; about; at; by; all; between; near; from; against; behind; beneath; along; beside; before; up; upon; towards; away; close; with; next; alongside; off; opposite; somewhere; amongst; among;

S.ms: higher than and to one side of; overlooking: in the hills above the capital | on the wall above the altar.Spatial3(1b)above
S.cprop: a physical entity lower in space than the POA
S.aprop: a physical entity higher in space than the comp.
S.com: corresponds to over 3(1b). This sense is often implicit in the core sense, and also in sense 4(2).

entry.S: 2. at a higher level or layer than: from his flat above the corner shop | bruises above both eyes.Spatial4(2)aboveThingSurmounted1 2a 3a 3b9.19Becoming_aware:Ground; Biological_area:Relative_location; Body_movement:Path; Cause_motion:Path; Location_of_light:Ground; Make_Noise:Place; Natural_features:Relative_location; Path_shape:Goal; Perception_active:Direction; Perception_experience:Direction; Placing:Goal; Posture:Location; Residence:Location; Roadways:Area; Self_motion:Area; Self_motion:Pathover, on top ofat; from; in; through; under; near; on; by; down; inside; about; above; to; among; round; along; between; of; beside; around; behind; beneath; across; over; into; right; towards; back; up; past; against; toward; after; beyond; straight; inlaid; within; ahead; below; amongst; his; outside; off; next; underneath; high; just; throughout; close; for; onto; halfway; deep; northwards; westward; well; with; anywhere; somewhere; the; aro; alongside; a; before; centrally; directly; upon; either; away; all; capacious; there; an; only; opposite; athwart; amidst; fairly; adjacent; upstream; shrewsbury; consistently; due; forwards; further; stinking; via; even; less; though; a physical entity that can have sth above itwide range of POSs. ms.df: higher in grade or rank than:
ms.ex: at a level above the common people.

S.cprop: noun, often an agent or person.
S.com: identical to over 5(2a)

ms.df: considered of higher status or worth than; too good for:
ms.ex: she married above her.

S.cprop: often gerund; otherwise personal or reflexive pronoun.
S.com: This is a sense not shared by "over"

ms.df: in preference to:
ms.ex: the firm cynically chose profit above car safety.

S.opreps: instead of, in place of, over

S.cprop: the rejected of two things

S.cprop: "the way"; "the road"; "the line"
S.srel: 1: figurative extension of progress representing a physical path

S.df: in company with or at the same time as:
S.ex: I was chosen, along with twelve other artists.
S.cprop: anything that can accompany the attachment point
S.com: Usually identical to with 1(1); ODE also gives "at the same time as" in omnibus def.

entry.S: • preposition N. Amer. also alongside of close to the side of; next to: she was sitting alongside him | as adv. the boat came alongside.Spatial1(1)alongsidePlaceBeside1 2a 3a9.27beside, by, next totangible object located in spaceverbs of location; physical objectscore: location besideIncludes the same figurative use that "next to" is allowed; such as contiguous ideas.

ms.df: together with and in cooperation with
ms.ex: a care assistant was working alongside him.

S.cprop: an agent, often identified by profession
S.srel: 3: extension to proximity as implying cooperation

ms.df: at the same time as or in coexistence with:
ms.ex: they aim to encourage coverage of disabled sport alongside able-bodied achievement.

S.cprop: wide range of NPs
S.srel: 3: extension of space proximity to temporal coexistence

entry.S: • preposition surrounded by; in the middle of: our dream home, set amid magnificent rolling countryside.Spatial1(1)amidThingSurrounding1 2a 3a 3b9.21between, among, amidst, amongnoun (often plural or collective) that surrounds the POAnoun or verb denoting action that unfolds in physical spacecore: encirclement

ms.df: in an atmosphere or against a background of:
ms.ex: talks broke down amid accusations of a hostile takeover bid.

S.cprop: an activity serving as backdrop for the POA
S.srel: 1: figurative extension of space to activity
S.com: Some affinity with in 7(5), FramingElement.

• preposition chiefly archaic or Scottish concerning; about: I'll say a few words anent the letter.Topic1(1)anentSubjectConsidered1 2a 3a9.7n, 9.57on, over, of, with respect toany NP; a subject of considerationverbs and nouns of info processing, storage, or communication; adjs denoting feelings and attitudescore: subjectScottish or archaic. ms.ex: our entire culture is built around those loyalties.

2. during the time of being (the thing specified): he had often been ill as a child.Backdrop2(2)asRole1 2a 2b*(when)a stage of life, usually preceded by indefinite article(often characterizes entire clause)core: characterizing role.Narrowly defined in ODE and not found in FrameNet; see treatment.

S.df: for a great enough distance to reach
S.ex: the river stretched away as far as he could see.
S.cprop: a destination or location
S.aprop: verbs of motion; nouns denoting travel or movement
S.com: effectively the same as to 1(1), though it suggests a limit on further forward progress.

S.ex: as for you, you'd better be quick.
S.cprop: a subject considered or related to another mentioned
S.aprop: (often first in sentence, acting as sentence adverb)
S.com: Similar to about 1(1), though syntactic behavior is different. Identical to concerning 1(1), with regard to 1(1).

entry.S: as from or of chiefly Brit. used to indicate the time or date from which something starts: as from 1 January, a free market will be created | I'm on the dole as of now.Temporal1(1)as ofas fromTimeOrigin3a 3b9.10froma date or point in timeverbs or adjectives denoting a state or activitycore: starting pointMainly Brit and same as from 3(2).

as from or of chiefly Brit. used to indicate the time or date from which something starts: as from 1 January, a free market will be created | I'm on the dole as of now.Temporal1(1)as ofas fromTimeOrigin3a 3b9.10froma date or point in timeverbs or adjectives denoting a state or activitycore: starting pointSame as from 3(2).

S.ex: as regards content, the programme will cover important current issues.
S.opreps: concerning, with respect to, as for, etc.
S.cprop: a subject considered or related to another mentioned
S.com: Similar to about 1(1), though syntactic behavior is different. Identical to concerning 1(1), with regard to 1(1).

S.ex: decisions as to which patients receive treatment.
S.opreps: concerning, with respect to, as for, etc.
S.cprop: a subject considered or related to another mentioned
S.com: Similar to about 1(1), though syntactic behavior is different. Identical to concerning 1(1), with regard to 1(1).

S.aprop: NP or whole clause when a disjunct.

2. expressing the time when an event takes place: the children go to bed at nine o'clock | his death came at a time when the movement was split.Temporal2(2)atTimePoint1 2a9.34, 9.40Avoiding:Time; Behind_the_scenes:Time; Cause_to_move_in_place:Time; Cause_to_wake:Time; Contacting:Time; Death:Time; Event:Time; Fluidic_motion:Time; Impact:Time; Manufacturing:Time; Placing:Time; Process_start:Time; Rite:Time; Social_event:Time; Waking_up:Timeinafter; at; for; in; on; during; prior; before; as; around; over; by; within; just; late; somewhat; a; four; next; several; towards; summer; while; 5; with; 48; eight; shortly; from; many; of; some; about; until; clock time or other time designationany word denoting an event or conditioncore: time

ms.df: (followed by a noun without a determiner) denoting a particular period of time:
ms.ex: the sea is cooler at night.

S.fepreps: at; for; on; after; from; just; through; during; in; with; because; given; as; without; by; later; of; before; a;
S.cprop: NPs denoting periods of time; no article; relatively fixed set (at night/dawn/daybreak etc.)
S.aprop: any word denoting an event or condition
S.srel: 2: specific to periods (rather than points) of time
S.com: FrameNet instances of this subsense are not separately tagged from main sense.

ms.df: (followed by a noun without a determiner) denoting the time spent by someone attending an educational institution or workplace:
ms.ex: it was at university that he first began to perform.

S.cprop: NPs denoting educational and work institutions
S.aprop: any word denoting an event or condition
S.srel: 2: specific to time in education or at work
S.com: This seems like a faux sense, and in any case is mainly Brit; US more often uses "in" for the education side of it (in college, in school).

entry.S: 3. denoting a particular point or level on a scale: prices start at £18,500 | driving at 50 mph.Scalar5(3)atLevel1 2a 3a*Being_employed:Rank; Cause_to_move_in_place:Periodicity; Commerce_buy:Money; Commerce_buy:Rate; Commerce_collect:Rate; Commerce_sell:Money; Commerce_sell:Rate; Communication_manner:Manner; Education_teaching:Level; Emitting:Speed; Expansion:Rate; Expensiveness:Asset; Fluidic_motion:Speed; Moving_in_place:Periodicity; Travel:Speedaround, inat; for; with; on; around; from; like; in; aged; between; just; under; to; NPs representing a point on a gradient; amounts; "a rate of"verbs and nouns denoting ranges; NPs that are genus to the comp.; adjs of valuecore: level on a scaleThis sense is to some degree a figurative extension of location; Quirk doesn't seem to treat it. Includes prices ("good value at $25.00), even when no scale is suggested.

ms.df: referring to someone's age:
ms.ex: at fourteen he began to work as a postman.

S.fepreps: below; of; over; from; under; aged; between; in; at;
S.cprop: whole numbers, in digits or spelled out
S.aprop: any word denoting an event or condition
S.srel: 2: specific to age in years or months

entry.S: 4. expressing a particular state or condition: his ready smile put her at ease | they were at a disadvantage.Backdrop7(4)atCondition1 2a 3a 3b(9.32)Commerce_sell:Manner; People:Descriptorinat; by; in; like; with; from; of; inside; within; on; across; next; down; outside; under; NPs completing idioms denoting conditioncopula; verbs denoting changecore: conditionSame as 5(4) of "in," Condition. Many uses are purely idiomatic. Quirk omits "at" from the list of preps discussed at 9.32, but it is clearly part of this group.

S.ms: expressing a relationship between an individual and a skill: boxing was the only sport I was any good at | she was getting much better at hiding her reactions.Tandem8(4a)at
S.fepreps: on; at; in; of; with; for; as; to; about;
S.cprop: a skill or ability; activity requiring skill (sometimes introduced by gerund)
S.aprop: verbs and adjs denoting judgment of ability
S.com: This could as easily be a core sense and it is probably not helpful to see it as a species of "condition."

entry.S: 5. by combining the resources or actions of (two or more people or other entities): we have created something between us | China and India between them account for a third of the global population.Doubles8(5)betweenPartiesJoined1 2a 3a9.32two parties joined to constitute a whole, or anaphoric pronoun referring to these.the two parties named separately (in case of complement anaphor); nouns denoting relationcore: combination of forces

S.un: In standard English it is correct to say between you and me but incorrect to say between you and I. Why is this? A preposition such as between takes the object case and is correctly followed by object pronouns such as me, him, her, and us rather than subject pronouns such as I, he, she, and we. Thus it is correct to say between us or between him and her and it is clearly incorrect to say between we or between he and she. The mistake between you and I arises from a confusion between what follows a preposition and what ordinarily comes at the beginning of a sentence in the subject case. Many people know that it is not correct to say John and me went to the shops and that the correct sentence is John and I went to the shops. Thus, people concerned about correcting mistakes in one context have assumed that ‘and me’ should in all cases be replaced by ‘and I’. In trying to avoid one kind of error, another one has been created.

1. Brit. (of goods) sold direct from: carpet tiles offered at a special price, ex stock.Backdrop1(1)CommerceexSourceOfGoods1 2a 3a*out of, fromcommercial terms denoting repository of inventory: stock, warehouse, etc.copula, verbs denoting transactionscore: source of goodsBrit.

S.cprop: nouns denoting commercial buildings
S.srel: 3: extension to charges applied to goods

entry.S: 2. Brit. not including: the cost is £5,000 ex VAT.Exception3(2)exThingExcluded1 2a*exclusive ofany NPverbscore: exclusive ofBusiness jargon for "exclusive of"

• preposition not including; other than: I was naked except for my socks | they work every day except Sunday.Exception1(1)exceptException1 2a 3c9.58but for, except for, with the exception of, aprt from, aside from, excepting, excluding, but, saveNP denoting sth exceptedNP or whole clause when a disjunct.core: exception

• preposition not including; other than: I was naked except for my socks | they work every day except Sunday.Exception1(1)except forException2a 2c9.58but for, except, with the exception of, aprt from, aside from, excepting, excluding, but, saveNP denoting sth exceptedNP or whole clause when a disjunct.core: exception

• preposition formal except for; apart from: excepting a scratched door, the car was in good condition.Exception1(1)exceptingException2a 2c9.8, 9.58but for, except for, with the exception of, aprt from, aside from, except, excluding, but, saveNP denoting sth exceptedNP or whole clause when a disjunct.core: exception

• preposition not taking someone or something into account; except: the holiday cost £180, excluding accommodation.Exception1(1)excludingException1 2a 2c9.8, 9.58dehors, exclusive ofNP denoting sth excludedNP or whole clause when a disjunct.core: exclusion
4. not including: prices are exclusive of VAT.Exception1(1)exclusive ofException1 2a 2c9.58dehors, excludingNP denoting sth excludedNP or whole clause when a disjunct.core: exclusion

• preposition in the absence of; if not: she longed to be with him and, failing that, to be alone.Backdrop1(1)failingOutcomeDesired2c9.8(otherwise)usually pronoun "that," referring to prev sentence or clausePP is usually a subjunct or conjunct, initial positioncore: desirable outcomeRarely used without "that" as complement. ="If x does not happen"

• preposition coming after or as a result of: police are hunting for two men following a spate of robberies in the area.Temporal1(1)followingEventPreceding1 2a9.8afteran event in time, usually the pastPP is often an adjunct connected to whole clausecore: triggering eventMore than "after," "following" is often used to indicate that the complement is the cause or inspiration for events referred to in the other clause.

S.ex: for all its clarity and style, the book is not easy reading.
S.opreps: despite, in spite of, notwithstanding, with all
S.cprop: NP denoting a contrast to sth in the other clause

S.df: in order to help or be useful to:
S.ex: a venue run for the benefit of the community.
S.cprop: person or institution capable of benefiting
S.com: This is a formal variation of for sense 3(3); slightly narrower in usage.

ms.df: in order to interest or impress (someone):
ms.ex: it was all an act put on for his benefit.

S.cprop: person or group whom behavior is aimed at
S.srel: 3: extension to use of 'benefit' in irony
S.com: Formulaic idiom used to indicate conscious attempts to influence. ODE notes form "for ____ benefit," where blank is filled by personal pronoun: this is probably most common.

entry.S: • preposition archaic or Scottish in addition to; besides as prep. no doubt he had many a sin on his soul, forbye murder.Backdrop1(1)forbyeforbyforbyeforbyThingSupplmented2a9.58beside, besidesany NPno pattern.core: additionIdentical to beside 3(2), and besides. Archaic Scots, not likely to be encountered.

• preposition also 'fore non-standard form of before: 'fore you know it, you're in trouble .Tributary1(1)fore'foreAll_Before1 2a 3a 3b*beforeSee before.See before.core: beforecontracted form of before, often written 'fore.

11. indicating a distinction: these fees are quite distinct from expenses.Tandem14(11)fromContrastor3b*Becoming_aware:Ground; Differentiation:Phenomenon_2in relation toat; from; in; through; under; near; on; by; down; inside; about; above; to; among; round; against; into; sth distinguished from the POA's referentverbs and adjectives noting difference or distinction

S.ex: three hundred and fifty years ago, give or take a few.
S.cprop: a unit of measure, often preceded by a number
S.aprop: PP works as adjunct or conjunct, modifying figure given in other clause

ms.df: apart from:
ms.ex: give or take the odd aircraft bit, there are few new products.

S.cprop: no pattern: NPs
S.aprop: occasionally first in sentence as a disjunct; otherwise, no pattern.
S.com: This is a subsense for convenience only; unrelated to main sense, and not common.

entry.S: • preposition taking into account: given the complexity of the task, they did a good job.Backdrop1(1)givenCircumstances2c9.8with regard to, in view of, consideringNP denoting accompanying circumstances(usually a subjunct/sentence adverb clause)core: circumstancesUsed mainly to denote mitigating or otherwise affecting circumstances.

• preposition Brit. (of time) past: it's gone half past eleven.Temporal1(1)HuntinggoneHour1*after, pastnumbers 1 to 12 (representing hours); noon, miday, or midnight; other clock expressionsafter copula or "had"core: time pastMainly Brit; same as after 3(1b) but with some usage limitations.

ms.df: (of age) older than:
ms.ex: she was gone sixty by then.

S.cprop: whole number denoting age
S.aprop: copula; rarely, a term denoting a person
S.srel: 3: extension to age as the mark passed, rather than the hour
S.com: Mainly Brit and informal. Similar to over 10(3), but limited to human age.

S.l: with or in or having regard to
S.ex: he made enquiries with regard to Beth.
S.opreps: as concerns, with respect to, etc.
S.cprop: abstract nouns; NP that often includes "circumstances"
S.aprop: only as a parenthetical conjunct, usually in midsentence
S.com: Used only as a formal formula, often in legal or ecclesiastical writing. Mainly Brit.

ms.ex: Mozart's Piano Concerto in E flat.

S.cprop: a musical key
S.aprop: a musical work, or a verb or composition
S.srel: 3: extension to musical key (as a medium)

S.opreps: per, as per, in accordance with
S.cprop: wide range of NPs; no pattern
S.com: A closer equivalent is "consistent with," not "according to," as ODE has it. Some affinity with "according to" 2(1a)

S.ex: members of the board were paid a small allowance in addition to their normal salary.
S.opreps: beside, besides, on top of, apart from
S.cprop: any NP
S.com: same as beside/besides/on top of

S.ex: we went on ahead in advance of the main group.
S.cprop: an event in time
S.aprop: no pattern; wide range of nouns and verbs
S.com: elegant variation on before or ahead of. ODE notes spatial or temporal use, but usage is overwhelmingly temporal.

S.df: in support of; for the purpose of raising money for:
S.ex: a charity show in aid of Leukaemia Research.
S.cprop: a party that can benefit from sth
S.com: similar to for 1(1) and 3(3); slightly narrower usage.

S.ex: dad demolished a shed in back of his barn.
S.cprop: an object locatable in space
S.aprop: nouns; verbs and verbal nouns of movement and location
S.com: same as behind 1(1) and 3(2).

S.cprop: NP denoting persons; personal pronoun
S.aprop: copula; action and perception verbs; NPs denoting persons
S.com: common, euphemistic idiom. Literal and blameless meaning is also possible.

ms.df: in undesirably close association with:
ms.ex: he was in bed with the Mob.

S.cprop: NP denoting persons; personal pronoun
S.aprop: copula; action and perception verbs; NPs denoting persons
S.srel: 3: extension to negative aspect of intimate association.
S.com: figurative extension of the idiom.

entry.S: 1. in the interests of a person, group, or principle: he campaigned on behalf of the wrongly convicted four.Tandem1(1)on behalf ofin behalf ofon someone's behalfon somebody's behalfon a person's behalfon my behalfon your behalfon his behalfon her behalfon our behalfon their behalfon its behalfbehalfBeneficiary1 3a9.11for, in aid ofNP denoting persons, groups, ideasnouns and verbs; no patterncore: benefitalso includes on X's behalf.

2. as a representative of: he had to attend the funeral on Mama's behalf.Tandem2(2)on behalf ofin behalf ofon someone's behalfon somebody's behalfon a person's behalfon my behalfon your behalfon his behalfon her behalfon our behalfon their behalfon its behalfPartyRepresented3a9.11for, instead of, on behalf ofa party represented by anotherverbscore: representationThis and previous also include on behalf of, on X's behalf.

S.df: in the event of (a particular situation):
S.ex: instructions about what to do in case of fire.
S.cprop: an event, situation, or circumstances
S.com: common idiom, analyzable as 2 PPs.

S.ex: in common with other officers I had to undertake guard duties.
S.cprop: any NP
S.aprop: usually predicates some form of have; pronouns something, anything, nothing typically occur as well.
S.com: Perhaps not profitable to view this as a PP.

S.ex: the US dollar went through a bad patch in 1986, in company with the oil market.
S.cprop: NPs denoting agents mainly
S.com: elegant variation on with 1(1)

S.ex: detectives are questioning two men in connection with alleged criminal damage.
S.opreps: on, over, of, with respect to, about, concerning
S.cprop: any NP; a subject of consideration
S.aprop: wide range of nouns and verbs; no pattern
S.com: slightly more limited in usage than, e.g., "with regard to," but essentially the same as other preps that share this Srtype.

S.df: in return for; on account of:
S.ex: he paid them in consideration of their services.
S.cprop: item or items in a transaction
S.aprop: an amount, or other item in transaction; verbs of payment and exchange
S.com: essentially the same as for 9(8); some common features with for 5(4).

entry.S: • preposition so as to violate the provisions of the publishing of misleading advertisements was a contravention of the Act | mass noun contravention of parking restrictions | there were repeated raids by one side upon the other in contravention of treaty terms.Backdrop1(1)Lawin contravention ofin contravention ofRule1 3a9.11againstNPs representing rules, laws, dogmasaction and stative verbs; nounscore: contraventioninfrequent, limited, specific usage; always indicates that some act or thought violates a rule, law, etc.

S.ex: in default of agreement the rent was to be determined by a surveyor.
S.cprop: a thing missing or not present; usually abstract
S.com: Same as 1(1) of "without"; infrequent and mainly in legal writing

S.ex: a top speed in excess of 20 knots.
S.cprop: a quantity, number, or quantifiable thing
S.com: Functions as intensive adjective, though parses as tandem PP.

S.l: in face or the face of
S.ex: her resolution in the face of the enemy.
S.cprop: NP denoting a contrary circumstance; often whole clause
S.aprop: typically disjunct with no clear attachment
S.com: some similarity to against 6(2b), but more specific and limited in usage.

ms.df: despite:
ms.ex: reform had been introduced in the face of considerable opposition.

S.opreps: in spite of, notwithstanding, for all, with all, despite
S.cprop: NP denoting a contrasting thing
S.srel: 2: specific to victory over confronting force

S.aprop: verbs of motion and placing; physical objects
S.com: same as before 2(2)

entry.S: 2. in the presence of: the teacher didn't want his authority challenged in front of the class.Backdrop3(2)in front ofPartyPresent2a 3a9.11(before)NP denoting agents or group of agentsaction verbs; negative clause often presentcore: presenceODE doesn't cover it, but "before" is used this way in formal contexts.

S.df: as a celebration of or expression of respect for.
S.cprop: NP denoting agents or group of agents
S.com: More specific than the sense of for that is its nonce equivalent.

S.df: as a celebration of or expression of respect for.
S.cprop: NP denoting agents or group of agents
S.com: More specific than the sense of for that is its nonce equivalent.

S.l: in or out of keeping with
S.ex: the cuisine is in keeping with the hotel's Edwardian character.
S.cprop: a practice, tradition, standard, statement, etc.
S.aprop: copula or as a subjunct without clear attachment
S.com: stock idiom; "more" and "not" often intervene between copula and this phrase.

entry.S: • preposition in phrase in lieu instead of the company issued additional shares to shareholders in lieu of a cash dividend.Tandem1(1)in lieulieuThingReplaced1 3a9.11, 9.12instead of, in place ofconcrete and abstract nouns, gerunds; $ amountsnouns; action verbscore: replacementsame as instead of but with many usages fixed by convention, esp. with reference to flowers (funerals) and amounts of bail bonds.

S.l: in the light of or in light of
S.ex: the exorbitant prices are explainable in the light of the facts.
S.cprop: an existing fact or condition
S.aprop: often a subjunct; no clear attachment
S.com: similar to many phrases that share this type, but more restricted in meaning.

S.l: in or out of line with
S.ex: remuneration is in line with comparable international organizations.
S.cprop: no pattern: sth already existing
S.aprop: often a subjunct; otherwise verbs of location and placement, often used figuratively
S.com: often equal to "consistent with"

entry.S: • preposition in memory of (a dead person): an openly revolutionary work in memoriam Che Guevara.Tandem1(1)in memoriamPartyCommemorated1*a dead personany NPcore: commemorationrare in the sense quoted in ODE.

S.ex: he was in desperate need of medical care.
S.cprop: wide range of NPs; common collocs are help, repair, improvement, treatment
S.aprop: no pattern; phrase is often an entire predicate after copula
S.com: often equal to "who needs" or "that needs"

entry.S: • preposition mass noun very likely to incur or to suffer from you could well place us both in peril | the movement is in peril of dying | count noun a setback to the state could present a peril to the regime.Tandem1(1)in peril ofin peril ofThreat1 3a9.11sth that poses a threat or possible adverse event; often gerundivecopula; verbs of placement used figuratively; nounscore: threatphrase plus complement always has same meaning, though complement type varies.

S.cprop: concrete and abstract nouns
S.com: equals "instead of"

entry.S: 1. according to (a particular relationship in size, amount, or degree) the pension was docked in proportion to earnings.Scalar1(1)in proportionGauge1 2a 3a*in relation tomainly quantifiable abstract nounsnouns; quantifying verbs, esp 'increase' and 'decrease'core: proportion

ms.df: in comparison with; in relation to:
ms.ex: the cuckoo's eggs are unusually small in proportion to its size.

S.cprop: nouns denoting 2nd term of comparison
S.aprop: 1st noun of compared term; verb or adj denoting content of comparison
S.srel: 3: extension to comparison as an indicator of proportion
S.com: This is technically an incorrect or at least imprecise use of the PP.

entry.S: • preposition in the legal case of; with regard to: the decision of the Court of Appeal in re Midland Railway Co's Agreement.Topic1(1)Lawin reSubjectConsidered1 2b 3a*with regard to, etc.legal cases, or some other subject under considerationnot enough evidence to identify a patterncore: legal case referencedrare outside legal writing; occasionally an elegant variation on "with regard to"

S.ex: war can only be explained with reference to complex social factors.
S.cprop: any NP constituting a subject of reference
S.aprop: copula; nouns denoting things that contain refs; also as subjunct

S.l: with or in or having regard to
S.ex: he made enquiries with regard to Beth.
S.cprop: any NP constituting a subject of reference
S.aprop: copula; nouns denoting things that contain refs; also as subjunct

S.df: in the context of; in connection with:
S.ex: there is an ambiguity in the provisions in relation to children's hearings.
S.opreps: in proportion to, with reference to
S.cprop: any NP
S.aprop: nouns, verbs, adjectives, copula; no real pattern

S.l: in respect of or with respect to
S.ex: the two groups were similar with respect to age, sex, and diagnoses.
S.cprop: any NP constituting a subject of reference
S.aprop: copula; nouns denoting things that contain refs; also as subjunct
S.com: same as "in respect to"; rare outside legal, formal, or Brit writing

S.df: so as to see or be seen from:
S.ex: I climbed the hill and came in sight of the house.
S.cprop: a physical, visible object
S.aprop: copula; verbs of location and placement; nouns

ms.df: within reach of; close to attaining:
ms.ex: he was safe for the moment and in sight of victory.

S.cprop: usually abstract NP denoting an aspiration
S.srel: 1: fig extension to an internal goal being visible as it is approached
S.com: little evidence for this usage.

S.ex: he was suddenly cold in spite of the sun.
S.opreps: despite, notwithstanding, for all, with all
S.cprop: NP denoting a contrasting thing

S.l: in terms of or in —— terms
S.ex: replacing the printers is difficult to justify in terms of cost.
S.opreps: with regard to, in view of
S.cprop: wide variety of NPs; sometimes wh-word clauses
S.aprop: often a subjunct or disjunct; otherwise, nearly anything

entry.S: 1. while undergoing a process of a new text book was in course of preparation.Temporal1(1)in course ofin the course ofTimeframe2a 3a 3b*in, duringNPs denoting fixed periods of time, often with modifiers; "period"wide range of POSs. No patterncore: timeframeBoth senses of "in the course of" correspond to the same numbered senses of "during".

2. during he was a friend to many people in the course of his life.Temporal2(2)in the course ofEventInTime1 2a 3a 3b*duringNPs denoting eventswide range of POSs. No pattern2: specific to events located in time

S.l: in face or the face of
S.ex: her resolution in the face of the enemy.
S.opreps: in spite of, notwithstanding, for all, with all, despite
S.cprop: NP denoting a contrasting thing
S.com: Perhaps worth watching out for the phrase "fly in the face of," which is not either sense of this PP.

ms.df: despite:
ms.ex: reform had been introduced in the face of considerable opposition.

S.cprop: NPs denoting activities, events, evidence
S.srel: 3: extension from contrastive to contradicting or confrontational
S.com: same as "faced with," currently not parsed as a PP.

S.l: after or in the fashion of
S.ex: she took servants for granted after the fashion of wealthy girls.
S.cprop: one whose behavior or work is imitated

S.df: dominated or affected by something undesirable or adverse:
S.ex: Britain was in the grip of a crime wave.
S.cprop: NPs denoting something malevolent and powerful
S.com: Fixed phrase with nearly invariable meaning.

S.l: in the light of or in light of
S.ex: the exorbitant prices are explainable in the light of the facts.
S.cprop: an existing fact or condition
S.aprop: often a subjunct; no clear attachment
S.com: similar to many phrases that share this type, but more restricted in meaning.

S.ex: the British are given pre-eminence in the matter of tea.
S.opreps: concerning, with respect to, as for, re, etc.
S.cprop: a subject considered or related to another mentioned

entry.S: • preposition engaged in or undergoing a process of he left his flat in the midst of a rainstorm.Activity1(1)in the midst ofin the midst ofActivity2a 3a 3b9.11amid, amidst, underan activity serving as backdrop for the POAaction verbscore: backdropSome affinity with in 7(5), FramingElement; same as amidst 2(1a)

S.df: bearing or using the name of a specified person or organization.
S.cprop: a person, organization, corporation, etc.
S.com: Least common of the three senses in ODE, though it is their core sense.

ms.df: for the sake of:
ms.ex: he withdrew his candidacy for the post in the name of party unity.

S.cprop: sth capable of benefiting or improving
S.srel: 3: extension to named party as beneficiary
S.com: most common of the three senses.

ms.df: by the authority of:
ms.ex: crimes committed in the name of religion.

S.cprop: a person, ruler, or other authority
S.srel: 3: extension to named party as authority

S.cprop: an employer or other paying agent
S.com: more restricted usage than preps that share this type; noun "pay" supplies the meaning of the other prep's POA.

S.ex: trouble arrived in the person of a short, moustached Berliner.
S.cprop: a person's name, or a personal description
S.aprop: mainly verbs denoting a wide range of activities
S.com: Odd phrase: substitutable by as, from, in, or by; no easy test to know which of these it is.

S.ex: retribution arrived in the shape of my irate father.
S.cprop: abstract and concrete nouns; little pattern
S.com: Not a frequent phrase. By far the overwhelming use of this phrase is literal.

ms.df: by way of; in the nature of:
ms.ex: there had been little or nothing in the shape of academic planning.

S.cprop: abstract verbal nouns
S.srel: 2: specific to things fulfilling a function
S.com: Even less frequent than the previous phrase.

S.cprop: NPs denoting something malevolent and powerful

ms.df: in spite of (opposition or difficulty):
ms.ex: the firm has expanded its building contracting division in the teeth of recession.

S.cprop: mainly abstract nouns denoting obstacles and forces
S.aprop: action verbs, verbal nouns, adjectives denoting qualities of character
S.srel: 3: extension to contradiction as an opposing force

S.df: in the middle of doing or dealing with something very difficult or painful:
S.ex: a friend was in the throes of a divorce.
S.cprop: an unpleasant activity serving as backdrop for the POA; often beginning as gerund
S.com: Similar to other senses sharing this type except experience described by the complement is nearly always unpleasant.

S.df: as a sign or symbol of:
S.ex: adults exchanging drinks around a pub bar in token of temporary friendship.
S.cprop: abstract nouns, many representing feelings or attitudes
S.com: rare. Same as "as a token of," which is not in the inventory but commoner.

S.df: because of; as a result of
S.opreps: on account of, for from, by reason of, because of
S.cprop: NP often describing an event or development
S.aprop: a clause for which the PP supplies the "why"

S.df: because of; as a result of
S.cprop: NP, concrete or abstract
S.aprop: a clause for which the PP supplies the "why"

entry.S: • preposition used to specify parts, species, members, or particulars of the general thing mentioned languages including Welsh and Gaelic | weapons were recovered from the house, including a shotgun.Membership1(1)includingMember19.8, 17.73any member of a class; clauses also.a generic nouncore: speciesNot treated as a prep by Quirk or FrameNet, though ODE labels it so. Syntax label assumes that the POA is always the generic term.

ms.df: containing (a specified element) as part of a whole:
ms.ex: all prices are inclusive of VAT.

S.cprop: any member of a class; clauses also.

entry.S: 2. prep. in less than (the period of time specified): the oven will have paid for itself inside 18 months.Temporal5(2)insidePeriodLimiting1 2a*withina period of timenouns and verbscore: period within which

S.ex: something inside of me wanted to believe him.

ms.ex: he was screaming like a banshee.

Two numbers are congruent modulo a given number if they give the same remainder when divided by that number.Quantity1(1)MathematicsmoduloModulus3b*a whole numberthe adjs "congruent" and "equivalent"; whole numberscore: modulusoccurs only in technical and mathematical writing

entry.S: 3. so as to be removed or separated from: threatening to tear the door off its hinges | they knocked $2,000 off the price | figurative it's a huge burden off my shoulders.Spatial4(3)offPlaceAbandoned1 2a 3a9.15, 9.18Arriving:Source; Body_movement:Source; Cause_harm:Result; Cause_harm:Victim; Cause_motion:Source; Cotheme:Source; Experiencer_obj:Result; Facial_expression:Location; Gesture:Message; Hair_configuration:Location; Ingest_substance:Delivery_device; Kidnapping:Source; Make_Noise:Manner; Manipulate_into_doing:Resulting_action; Motion:Source; Part_orientational:Whole; Perception_experience:Direction; Removing:Source; Self_motion:Manner; Theft:Source; Theft:Victimfrom; away; off; out; to; half; into; on; at; up; in; of; back; with; about; across; for; the; towards; beside; between; behind; around; near; like; insistently; softly; under; through; noisily; above; over; right; well; places; clean; and; three; two; by; as; obviously; a; place or object with spatial, or figuratively spatial dimensions; agentive with some POAsverbs of partition, motion, violencecore: partitive movement"off of" can substitute in all cases; ODE lumps much figurative use here.

ms.ex: I took a couple of days off work.

S.cprop: NPs denoting typical occupation (work, school, etc.)
S.srel: 3: extension to absence as partitive idea
S.com: "off of" can substitute in all cases.

ms.df: abstaining from:
ms.ex: he managed to stay off alcohol.

S.cprop: NPs denoting drink, drugs, foods or food groups
S.srel: 3: extension to abstinence as partitive idea
S.com: "off of" can substitute in all cases.

entry.S: 4. informal having a temporary dislike of: he's running a temperature and he's off his food.Tandem7(4)offSubstanceAbandoned2a 3a(9.32)NPs denoting foodscopula and other verbscore: temporary abandonment.Mainly British.

S.un: The compound preposition off of is used interchangeably with the preposition off in a context such as she picked it up off of the floor (compared with she picked it up off the floor). The use of off of is recorded from the 16th century (and was used commonly by Shakespeare, for example) and is logically parallel to the standard out of, but is not accepted in standard modern English. Today off of is restricted to dialect and informal contexts, particularly in the US.

un.p: The preposition onto written as one word (instead of on to) is recorded from the early 18th century and has been widely used ever since, but is still not wholly accepted as part of standard English (unlike into, for example). Many style guides still advise writing it as two words, and that is the practice followed in this dictionary. However, in US English onto is more or less the standard form and this is likely to become the case in British English before long. When used in the specialized mathematics sense, the form is invariably onto.

Nevertheless, it is important to maintain a distinction between the preposition onto or on to and the use of the adverb on followed by the preposition to: she climbed on to (or onto) the roof but let's go on to (not onto) the next point.

S.l: in or out of keeping with
S.df: not in harmony or conformity with

S.l: in or out of line with

S.df: to the outside or on the far side of:

S.com: In addition to "beside" also suggests "beyond one limit of"

ms.df: extending above (an area) from a vantage point:
ms.ex: views over Hyde Park.

S.fepreps: out; around; along; inside; over; across; in; into; towards; about; past; through; up; behind; back; between; beyond; down; from; off; on; under; above; below; beneath; deep; northwards; westward; outside; after; among; toward; for; at; upon; right; of; as;
S.cprop: an area; sth that can be viewed or that foregrounds a view

entry.S: 2. at a higher level or layer than: his flat was over the shop.Spatial4(2)overThingSurmounted1 2a 3a 3b9.19Body_movement:Goal; Change_posture:Path; Perception_experience:Body_part; Posture:Path; Roadways:Pathabove, on top ofagainst; to; out; over; into; on; behind; beneath; in; about; above; across; along; around; beside; at; before; by; up; onto; upon; towards; away; under; half; with; between; down; inside; through; from; within; of; alongside; a physical entity that can have sth above itwide range of POSs. ms.df: expressing authority or control:
ms.ex: editorial control over what is included.

ms.ex: I'd choose the well-known brand over that one.

S.com: It is perhaps not helpful to locate this as a species of spatial "above."

ms.df: expressing majority:
ms.ex: the predominance of Asian over African managers in the sample.

S.cprop: the lesser of two quantities
S.aprop: nouns expressing majority; the greater of two

ms.df: higher in volume or pitch than:

4. expressing passage or trajectory across: she trudged over the lawn.Spatial11(4)overThingTraversed2a 3a9.24Cotheme:Distance; Cotheme:Path; Departing:Path; Motion_noise:Area; Motion_noise:Path; Reading:Text; Self_motion:Area; Self_motion:Path; Travel:Pathacross, throughfor; over; to; along; beyond; round; through; across; around; down; from; past; up; towards; in; between; nowhere; out; right; low; by; via; back; at; toward; about; on; among; below; beneath; all; under; after; alongside; beside; behind; amongst; inside; somewhere; anywhere; close; outside; throughout; near; upon; before; off; above; consistently; just; underneath; onto; due; forwards; into; further; straight; the; stinking; even; less; though; a physical entity that can be crossed; nouns denoting distance; reading materialverbs and verbal nouns of motion (and reading)core: movement acrossThis has deep affinities with core senses of through and with across; the choice of over perhaps suggests that the thing negotiated is a short and unimportant stage in the main process. Also included: constructions such as "skim over" and "look over" when they apply to reading material.

ms.df: beyond and falling or hanging from:

• preposition in the matter of (used typically as the first word in the heading of an official document or to introduce a reference in a formal letter): re: invoice 87.Topic1(1)reSubjectConsidered2a 2c9.7n,9.57concerning, with respect to, as for, re, etc.a subject considered or related to another mentioned; a legal caseverbs of communication; whole clauses. Stands alone in legal and formal contexts.core: subject

ms.df: about; concerning:
ms.ex: I saw the deputy head re the incident.

S.cprop: any NP; a subject of consideration
S.aprop: verbs and nouns of info processing, storage, or communication; adjs denoting feelings and attitudes
S.com: nonstandard variant of about 1(1)

S.un: It is often said that, strictly speaking, re should be used in headings and references, as in Re: Ainsworth versus Chambers, but not as a normal word meaning ‘about’, as in I saw the deputy head re the incident. However, the evidence suggests that re is now widely used in the second context in official and semi-official contexts, and is now generally accepted. It is hard to see any compelling logical argument against using it as an ordinary English word in this way.

S.un: Traditional grammar holds that personal pronouns following than should be in the subjective rather than the objective case: he is smaller than she rather than he is smaller than her. This is based on an analysis of than by which than is a conjunction and the personal pronoun (‘she’) is standing in for a full clause: he is smaller than she is. However, it is arguable that than in this context is not a conjunction but a preposition, similar grammatically to words like with, between, or for. In this case the personal pronoun is objective: he is smaller than her is standard in just the same way as, for example, I work with her is standard (not I work with she). Whatever the grammatical analysis, the evidence confirms that sentences like he is smaller than she are uncommon in modern English and only ever found in formal contexts. Uses involving the objective personal pronoun, on the other hand, are almost universally accepted. For more explanation, see usage at personal pronoun and between.

un.p: In most contexts, till and until have the same meaning and are interchangeable. The main difference is that till is generally considered to be the more informal of the two, and occurs less frequently than until in writing. Until also tends to be the natural choice at the beginning of a sentence: until very recently, there was still a chance of rescuing the situation.

Interestingly, while it is commonly assumed that till is an abbreviated form of until (the spellings 'till and 'til reflect this), till is in fact the earlier form. Until appears to have been formed by the addition of Old Norse und ‘as far as’ several hundred years after the date of the first records for till.

• preposition more formal term for on, especially in abstract senses: it was based upon two principles | a school's dependence upon parental support.Spatial1(1)uponSurfaceSupporting1 2a 3a9.15-17Body_movement:Area; Body_movement:Goal; Cause_impact:Impactee; Change_posture:Goal; Dispersal:Goal_area; Placing:Goal; Posture:Locationon, atop, above, overover; round; around; at; on; across; between; in; by; behind; upon; under; above; inside; near; within; against; to; into; out; low; beneath; about; back; before; beside; close; up; onto; away; off; with; straight; next; alongside; opposite; all; along; through; one; anywhere; a; among; an; from; deep; somewhere; the; below; down; either; right; directly; just; outside; capacious; underneath; towards; there; only; athwart; a supporting surface or entityconcrete nouns; verbs of locationcore: contact with surfacesNote that 'upon' sense numbering duplicates 'on' numbering but many senses are not realized with 'upon'.

S.un: The preposition upon has the same core meaning as the preposition on. However, in modern English upon tends to be restricted to more formal contexts or to established phrases and idioms, as in once upon a time and row upon row of seats.
